variable-test.description: This is one of a set of scenarios that test tracking of maximum wait time for vaccination, specifically, that maximum wait time does not count units whose vaccination is canceled. In this scenario, one unit waits 2 days for vaccination, then another waits 4 days but is destroyed instead of vaccinated.
variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
variable-test.parameter-description:
For cattle, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days, and immunity lasts 3 days. For pigs, the latent period lasts 3 days and the other durations are the same.
The probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of detection vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1.
All cattle units within 1 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. Vaccination resources allow for 1 unit to be vaccinated 2 days after the first detection, and another unit 6 days after the first detection.
All cattle units within 1 km of a detected pig unit will be destroyed. Destruction resources allow for 1 unit to be vaccinated each day starting at 6 days after the first detection.
There is no spread.
What should happen: - On day 1 the infected units (0 and 1) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and will trigger a vaccination ring. Unit 2 will be marked for vaccination. - On day 4 unit 2 will be vaccinated, after a 2-day wait. 2 days is now the maximum wait time. Also on day 4, unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and will trigger a vaccination ring. Unit 4 will be marked for vaccination. - On day 8 unit 4 will be destroyed. The maximum wait time will still be 2 days, the wait time for the only unit that was actually vaccinated.

deterministic-test.short-name: double-detected units not counted twice toward vaccination threhold
deterministic-test.description: There can be more than one means of detection. In this test, the threshold for vaccination is 3 detected units. Two units are detected, the first by clinical signs, the second by clinical signs and a positive test result on the same day. No vaccinations should be done, because only 2 units have been detected (the unit that is detected twice should not count twice toward the vaccination threshold). This test failed in version 3.2.5 and was fixed in 3.2.6.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <nharve01@uoguelph.ca>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For sheep (unit 0), the infectious subclinical period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 1 day, and immunity lasts 5 days. For cattle (unit 1) and pigs (unit 2), the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 1 day, and immunity lasts 5 days.
Sheep units send 1 shipment per day to cattle units. The distance of shipment is 10 km, and the probability of infection is 1. There are no other kinds of contact.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Direct contacts out of a detected unit will be traced. There is no delay to trace, and tracing success is 100%. Units found by trace will be examined; if no signs of disease are detected, they will be tested. A test requires 1 day and has 100% sensitivity and specificity.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 3 units. Pig units within 15 km of a diseased cattle unit will be vaccinated. Vaccination resources allow for 10 units to be vaccinated per day.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 will be Infectious Subclinical. It will ship to and infect unit 1. - On day 2 unit 1 will be Latent. Unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. Unit 0 will be detected. Because it is a sheep unit, it will not trigger a vaccination ring. However, it will trigger a trace, which will lead to unit 1. Unit 1 will be examined, but no clinical signs of disease will be found (it is still Latent). A test will be ordered. - On day 3 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected by clinical signs. Also on this day, a positive test result will come back for unit 1. However, since only 1 units have been detected up to this point, no vaccination will be done.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on 1 detection in any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on number of detections. There are 4 units of type A, A, B, and C, which get detected one per day. Above those are a row of units of type D, which get vaccinated if/when a vaccination program is initiated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by detection of 1 unit of any type.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For all production types, there is no latent period and the clinical period lasts 10 days.
Airborne spread is set up such that infection will spread from unit 1 (lower row, far left) across the lower row, with 1 new unit infected each day. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 1 unit of any type.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - On day 2 the top row of units will be vaccinated. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on 3 detections in any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on number of detections. There are 4 units of type A, A, B, and C, which get detected one per day. Above those are a row of units of type D, which get vaccinated if/when a vaccination program is initiated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by detection of 3 units of any type.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
Parameter setup is similar to trigger on 1 detection in any type above, but vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 3 units of any type.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. - On day 2 unit 2 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. - On day 3 unit 3 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and, since this is the 3rd detection, a vaccination program will be initiated. - On day 4 the top row of units will be vaccinated. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on 2 detections in type A
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on number of detections. There are 4 units of type A, A, B, and C, which get detected one per day. Above those are a row of units of type D, which get vaccinated if/when a vaccination program is initiated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by detection of 2 units of type A.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
Parameter setup is similar to trigger on 1 detection in any type above, but vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 2 units of type A.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. - On day 2 unit 2 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and, since this is the 2nd detection of an A unit, a vaccination program will be initiated. - On day 3 the top row of units will be vaccinated. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on 3 detections in type A
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on number of detections. There are 4 units of type A, A, B, and C, which get detected one per day. Above those are a row of units of type D, which get vaccinated if/when a vaccination program is initiated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by detection of 3 units of type A (which never happens).
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
Parameter setup is similar to trigger on 1 detection in any type above, but vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 3 units of type A.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. - On day 2 unit 2 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. - On day 3 unit 3 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. This is the 3rd detection, but there have only been 2 detections of A units and 1 of a B unit, so vaccination will not be initiated. - On day 4 unit 4 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Vaccination still will not be initiated. - The simulation will end when all units are either Destroyed or Susceptible.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on 1 detection in type B or C
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on number of detections. There are 4 units of type A, A, B, and C, which get detected one per day. Above those are a row of units of type D, which get vaccinated if/when a vaccination program is initiated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by detection of 1 unit of type B or C.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
Parameter setup is similar to trigger on 1 detection in any type above, but vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 1 unit of type B or C.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. This unit is type A so it does not get counted towards initiating vaccination. - On day 2 unit 2 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Again this unit is type A so it does not get counted towards initiating vaccination. - On day 3 unit 3 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. This unit is of type B, so vaccination will be initiated. - On day 4 the top row of units will be vaccinated. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on 1 detection in type C
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on number of detections. There are 4 units of type A, A, B, and C, which get detected one per day. Above those are a row of units of type D, which get vaccinated if/when a vaccination program is initiated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by detection of 1 unit of type C.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
Parameter setup is similar to trigger on 1 detection in any type above, but vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 1 unit of type C.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. This unit is type A so it does not get counted towards initiating vaccination. - On day 2 unit 2 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Again this unit is type A so it does not get counted towards initiating vaccination. - On day 3 unit 3 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. Again this unit is type B so it does not get counted towards initiating vaccination. This - On day 4 unit 4 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. This unit is of type C, so vaccination will be initiated. - On day 5 the top row of units will be vaccinated. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on 3 detections in type A or 2 detections in type B or C
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on number of detections. There are 4 units of type A, A, B, and C, which get detected one per day. Above those are a row of units of type D, which get vaccinated if/when a vaccination program is initiated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by detection of 3 units of type A or detection of 2 units of type B or C.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
Parameter setup is similar to trigger on 1 detection in any type above, but vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 3 units of type A (trigger #1) or 2 units of type B or C (trigger #2).
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 1 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. This makes 1 unit of type A detected, not enough to initiate vaccination. - On day 2 unit 2 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. This makes 2 units of type A detected, not enough to initiate vaccination. - On day 3 unit 3 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. This makes 1 unit of type B detected, not enough to initiate vaccination. - On day 4 unit 4 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected. This makes 1 unit of type B and 1 unit of type C detected, so vaccination will be initiated by trigger #2. - On day 5 the top row of units will be vaccinated. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on 4 detections over 3 days, any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on rate of detections. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by detection of 4 units over 3 days, any production type.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 0, 1, 1, 0, 2, 1, 1, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 4 units over 3 days (1.333 units per day), in units of any type.
What should happen: - Day 1: 0 detections, count over the past 3 days = 0. Rate = 0/3 = 0. - Day 2: 1 detection, count over the past 3 days = 1. Rate = 1/3 = 0.333. - Day 3: 1 detection, count over the past 3 days = 2. Rate = 2/3 = 0.667. - Day 4: 0 detections, count over the past 3 days = 2. Rate = 2/3 = 0.667. - Day 5: 2 detections, count over the past 3 days = 3. Rate = 3/3 = 1.0. - Day 6: 1 detection, count over the past 3 days = 3. Rate = 3/3 = 1.0. - Day 7: 1 detection, count over the past 3 days = 4. Vaccination will be initiated. - Day 8: 1 detection, count over the past 3 days = 3. The H unit will be vaccinated on this day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on 6 detections over 4 days, any type, reach equivalent rate 1.5 by 2 days
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on rate of detections. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by detection of 6 units over 4 days, any production type. The equivalent rate (1.5 units per day) is reached after only 2 days, but that should not trigger detection, since the point of counting the number of detections over 4 days is to smooth out spikes.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 1, 2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 6 units over 4 days, in units of any type.
What should happen: - Day 1: 1 detection, count over the past 4 days = 1. - Day 2: 2 detections, count over the past 4 days = 3. - There are no more detections after this point and vaccination will not be triggered.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on EDR 1.5 measured over last 3 days divided by 3 days before that
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination on EDR. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by an EDR of 1.5 or higher, measured by detections in the last 3 days divided by detections in the 3 days before that.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 0, 0, 2, 0, 0, 1, 2, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins when the EDR is 1.5 or higher, based on detections in units of any type.
What should happen: - Day 1: 0 detections, EDR = (0+0+0)/(0+0+0) = undefined. - Day 2: 0 detections, EDR = (0+0+0)/(0+0+0) = undefined. - Day 3: 2 detections, EDR = (2+0+0)/(0+0+0) = undefined. - Day 4: 0 detections, EDR = (0+2+0)/(0+0+0) = undefined. - Day 5: 0 detections, EDR = (0+0+2)/(0+0+0) = undefined. - Day 6: 1 detection, EDR = (1+0+0)/(2+0+0) = 0.5, too low. - Day 7: 2 detections, EDR = (2+1+0)/(0+2+0) = 1.5. Vaccination will be initiated. - Day 8: 1 detection. The H unit will be vaccinated on this day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger 1 day after first detection in any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination a given number of days after the first detection. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered 1 day after the first detection in any production type.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 0, 2, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins 1 day after the first detection, based on detections in units of any type.
What should happen: - Day 1: 0 detections. - Day 2: 1 detection. First detection. - Day 3: 1 detection. 1 day after 1st detection. The H unit will be vaccinated on this day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger 2 days after first detection in any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination a given number of days after the first detection. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered 2 days after the first detection in any production type.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 0, 2, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins 2 days after the first detection, based on detections in units of any type.
What should happen: - Day 1: 0 detections. - Day 2: 1 detection. First detection. - Day 3: 1 detection. 1 day after 1st detection. - Day 4: 0 detections. 2 days after 1st detection. The H unit will be vaccinated on this day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger 2 days after first detection in type C
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination a given number of days after the first detection. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered 2 days after the first detection in a unit of type C.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 2, 0, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins 2 days after the first detection, based on detections in units of type C.
What should happen: - Day 1: 0 detections. - Day 2: 1 detection of an A unit. - Day 3: 1 detection of a B unit. - Day 4: 0 detections. - Day 5: 1 detection of a C unit. First detection of the desired type. - Day 6: 2 detections. 1 day after 1st detection. - Day 7: 0 detections. 2 days after 1st detection. The H unit will be vaccinated on this day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger 5 days after first detection in type A or 3 days after first detection in type B
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination a given number of days after the first detection. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered 5 days after the first detection in a unit of type A or 3 days after the first detection in a unit of type B. (The B unit will be detected later, but will trigger vaccination first.)
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 2, 0, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins 5 days after the first detection in units of type A or 3 days after the first detection in units of type B.
What should happen: - Day 1: 0 detections. - Day 2: 1 detection of an A unit. First vaccination should happen on day 2+5 = 7. - Day 3: 1 detection of a B unit. First vaccination should happen on day 3+3 = 6. - Day 4: 0 detections. - Day 5: 1 detection of a C unit. - Day 6: 2 detections, D and E units. The H unit will be vaccinated on this day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on detection in 1 group (A,B)
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination once detections have occurred in a given number of production type groups. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered when detections have occurred in 1 group, containing types A and B.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins after detection has occurred in 1 group. The group contains production types A and B.
What should happen: - Day 1: 1 detection of an A unit. Vaccination will be initiated. - Day 2: 1 The H unit will be vaccinated on this day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on detection in 1 group (C,D)
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination once detections have occurred in a given number of production type groups. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered when detections have occurred in 1 group, containing types C and D.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins after detection has occurred in 1 group. The group contains production types C and D.
What should happen: - Day 1: 1 detection of an A unit. - Day 2: 1 detection of a B unit. - Day 3: 1 detection of a C unit. Vaccination will be initiated. - Day 4: 1 The H unit will be vaccinated on this day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on detection in 2 groups (A,B,C) (E,F)
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination once detections have occurred in a given number of production type groups. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered when detections have occurred in 2 groups. One group contains types A, B, and C, and the other group contains types E and F.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical.
Vaccination begins after detection has occurred in 2 groups. One group contains types A, B, and C, and the other group contains types E and F.
What should happen: - Day 1: 1 detection of an A unit. Detection has now occurred in group 1. - Day 2: 1 detection of a B unit. - Day 3: 1 detection of a C unit. - Day 4: 1 detection of a D unit. - Day 5: 1 detection of an E unit. Detection has now occurred in a second group. Vaccination will be initiated. - Day 6: 1 The H unit will be vaccinated on this day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at this point.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on unit waiting 1 day for destruction, 0 destruction capacity
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination once units have been waiting a given number of days for destruction. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered when any unit has been waiting 1 day for destruction.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical. There is no capacity to destroy diseased units.
Vaccination begins after any unit has been waiting 1 day for destruction.
What should happen: - Day 1: 1 detection of an A unit. - Day 2: 1 detection of a B unit. By the end of this day, the A unit counts as having been waiting for 1 day, so vaccination will be initiated. - Day 3: 1 detection of a C unit. The H unit will be vaccinated on this day.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on unit waiting 3 days for destruction, 0 destruction capacity
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination once units have been waiting a given number of days for destruction. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered when any unit has been waiting 3 days for destruction.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical. There is no capacity to destroy diseased units.
Vaccination begins after any unit has been waiting 3 days for destruction.
What should happen: - Day 1: 1 detection of an A unit. - Day 2: 1 detection of a B unit. By the end of this day, the A unit counts as having been waiting for 1 day. - Day 3: 1 detection of a C unit. The A unit counts as having been waiting for 2 days. - Day 4: 1 detection of a D unit. The A unit counts as having been waiting for 3 days, so vaccination will be initiated. - Day 5: 1 detection of an E unit. The H unit will be vaccinated on this day.

variable-test.short-name: trigger on unit waiting 3 days for destruction, destruction capacity 1 unit/day for 3 days
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test triggering vaccination once units have been waiting a given number of days for destruction. There are 8 units of types A-H, all starting latent, so the disease parameters can be manipulated to produce any number of newly Clinical units to detect on a particular day. The H unit is the one that gets vaccinated.
In this test, vaccination is triggered when any unit has been waiting 3 days for destruction.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The production types latent periods are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1. Detection occurs on the first day clinical. There is capacity to destroy 1 unit per day for the first 3 days.
Vaccination begins after any unit has been waiting 3 days for destruction.
What should happen: - Day 1-3: The A, B, and C units will be detected. Each of them will be destroyed the day after it is detected. - Day 4: The D unit is detected. Because capacity to destroy units has run out, this will be the one that initiates vaccination. - Day 5-7: These count as the 3 days that the D unit is waiting. - Day 8: The H unit will be vaccinated on this day.

variable-test.short-name: stop vaccination after 3 days with no detections (baseline)
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test stopping and restarting vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, a baseline, vaccination is initiated but not stopped.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that only unit 2 will be detected during this simulation.
For production type B, the latent and infectious subclinical period are both 1 day, and then the herd goes directly to immune. This ensures that neither of the B units will be detected during this simulation.
Vaccination begins after 1 detection. There is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day.
There is no rule for stopping vaccination.
What should happen: - Day 1: Unit 2 will be subclinical. - Day 2: Unit 2 will be clinical. It will be detected and this will initiate a vaccination program. - Days 3-8: On each day, 1 C unit will be vaccinated.

variable-test.short-name: stop vaccination after 3 days with no detections 1
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test stopping and restarting vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, there is only a single detection, and 3 days after that vaccination is stopped.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that only unit 2 will be detected during this simulation.
For production type B, the latent and infectious subclinical period are both 1 day, and then the herd goes directly to immune. This ensures that neither of the B units will be detected during this simulation.
Vaccination begins after 1 detection. There is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: Unit 2 will be subclinical. - Day 2: Unit 2 will be clinical. It will be detected and this will initiate a vaccination program. - Days 3-5: On each day, 1 C unit will be vaccinated, for a total of 3 units. Since there are no new detections during these 3 days, vaccination will be stopped. - Day 6: There should be no more vaccinations from this day forward.

variable-test.short-name: stop vaccination after 3 days with no detections 2
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test stopping and restarting vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, there is 1 detection (which triggers vaccination), another detection 2 days later, and 3 days after that vaccination is stopped.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the latent period is 2 days, and the infectious subclinical period is 1 day.
For production type B, the latent and infectious subclinical period are both 1 day, and then the herd goes directly to immune. This ensures that neither of the B units will be detected during this simulation.
Vaccination begins after 1 detection. There is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: Unit 2 will be subclinical. - Day 2: Unit 2 will be clinical. It will be detected and this will initiate a vaccination program. - Day 3: 1 C unit will be vaccinated. - Day 4: Unit 1 will be clinical. It will be detected. 1 C unit will be vaccinated. - Day 5-7: On each day, 1 C unit will be vaccinated, for a total of 5 units since vaccination began. Since there are no new detections during these 3 days, vaccination will be stopped. - Day 8: There should be no more vaccinations from this day forward.

variable-test.short-name: stop vaccination after 3 days with no detections, restart, same capacity chart
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test stopping and restarting vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, there is 1 detection which triggers vaccination of the C units. 3 days after that vaccination is stopped, so not all of the C units get vaccinated. A second detection causes the vaccination program to be re-started with D units added to the vaccination queue. The same vaccination capacity chart applies the second time the vaccination program is initiated.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that of the A units at the center of circle 1, only unit 2 will be detected during this simulation.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 6 days, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that of the B units at the center of circle 2, only unit 3 will be detected during this simulation, a few days after unit 2.
Vaccination begins after 1 detection. There is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: Unit 2 will be subclinical. - Day 2: Unit 2 will be clinical. It will be detected and this will initiate a vaccination program. There should be 6 C units awaiting vaccination. - Day 3-5: On each day, 1 C unit will be vaccinated, for a total of 3 units since vaccination began. Since there are no new detections during these 3 days, vaccination will be stopped. When vaccination is stopped, the queue of units awaiting vaccination is emptied, the number of units awaiting vaccination should drop to 0. - Day 7: Unit 3 will be clinical. It will be detected and this will re-initiate a vaccination program. There should be 6 D units awaiting vaccination. - Day 8-10: On each day, 1 D unit will be vaccinated. Since there are no new detections during these 3 days, vaccination will be stopped again.

variable-test.short-name: stop vaccination after 3 days with no detections, restart, different capacity chart
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test stopping and restarting vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, there is 1 detection which triggers vaccination of the C units. 3 days after that vaccination is stopped, so not all of the C units get vaccinated. A second detection causes the vaccination program to be re-started with D units added to the vaccination queue. A different vaccination capacity chart applies the second time the vaccination program is initiated.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that of the A units at the center of circle 1, only unit 2 will be detected during this simulation.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 6 days, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that of the B units at the center of circle 2, only unit 3 will be detected during this simulation, a few days after unit 2.
Vaccination begins after 1 detection. The first time vaccination is initiated, there is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day. The second time vaccination is initiated (and subsequent times), the vaccination capacity goes 1 unit on the first day, 2 units on the second day, and 3 units on the third day and forward.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: Unit 2 will be subclinical. - Day 2: Unit 2 will be clinical. It will be detected and this will initiate a vaccination program. There should be 6 C units awaiting vaccination. - Day 3-5: On each day, 1 C unit will be vaccinated, for a total of 3 units since vaccination began. Since there are no new detections during these 3 days, vaccination will be stopped. When vaccination is stopped, the queue of units awaiting vaccination is emptied, the number of units awaiting vaccination should drop to 0. - Day 7: Unit 3 will be clinical. It will be detected and this will re-initiate a vaccination program. There should be 6 D units awaiting vaccination. - Day 8: 1 D unit will be vaccinated. - Day 9: 2 D units will be vaccinated. - Day 10: 3 D units will be vaccinated. Since there were no new detections during the 3 days 8-10, vaccination will be stopped again.

deterministic-test.short-name: retrospective vaccination 0 days, 3 detections to trigger
deterministic-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test retrospective vaccination. There are 2 rows of units, cattle across the bottom and pigs across the top. Infection spreads across the row of cattle units, resulting in 1 detection per day when the units are turning Clinical. When a cattle unit is detected, a small vaccination circle is drawn, covering just the pig unit directly above that cattle unit.
In this test, vaccination is initiated once 3 infected units have been detected. Retrospective vaccination is given as 0 days.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle (the bottom row of units), the latent period lasts 1 day, then the unit becomes infectious clinical. Direct contact spread is set up such that each unit infects the one to its right.
Diseased cattle units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 3 units. Retrospective vaccination is set at 0 days. Pig units within 0.75 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. Vaccination resources allow for 1 unit to be vaccinated per day.
What should happen: - Day 1: Unit 0 will be latent. It will infect unit 1. - Day 2-5: On each of these days, a detection will occur, starting with unit 0 on day 2 and ending with unit 3 on day 5. - Day 4: The 3rd detection (unit 2) occurs on this day. A vaccination program will be initiated, and the pig unit directly above unit 2 (unit 6) will be added to the vaccination queue. - Day 5: Unit 6 will be vaccinated (its state will show as vaccine immune on day 6). Unit 3 is detected on this day, and unit 7 is added to the vaccination queue. - Day 6: Unit 7 will be vaccinated (its state will show as vaccine immune on day 7).

deterministic-test.short-name: retrospective vaccination 1 day, 3 detections to trigger
deterministic-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test retrospective vaccination. There are 2 rows of units, cattle across the bottom and pigs across the top. Infection spreads across the row of cattle units, resulting in 1 detection per day when the units are turning Clinical. When a cattle unit is detected, a small vaccination circle is drawn, covering just the pig unit directly above that cattle unit.
In this test, vaccination is initiated once 3 infected units have been detected. Retrospective vaccination is given as 1 day.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle (the bottom row of units), the latent period lasts 1 day, then the unit becomes infectious clinical. Direct contact spread is set up such that each unit infects the one to its right.
Diseased cattle units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 3 units. Retrospective vaccination is set at 1 day. Pig units within 0.75 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. Vaccination resources allow for 1 unit to be vaccinated per day.
What should happen: - Day 1: Unit 0 will be latent. It will infect unit 1. - Day 2-5: On each of these days, a detection will occur, starting with unit 0 on day 2 and ending with unit 3 on day 5. - Day 4: The 3rd detection (unit 2) occurs on this day. A vaccination program will be initiated, and the pig unit directly above unit 2 (unit 6) will be added to the vaccination queue. Unit 5 will also be added to the vaccination queue, and it will count as an older vaccination request, because it is in a ring around unit 1 which was detected 1 day ago (retrospective). - Day 5: Unit 5 will be vaccinated (its state will show as vaccine immune on day 6). Unit 3 is detected on this day, and unit 7 is added to the vaccination queue. - Day 6: Unit 6 will be vaccinated (its state will show as vaccine immune on day 7). - Day 7: Unit 7 will be vaccinated (its state will show as vaccine immune on day 8).

deterministic-test.short-name: retrospective vaccination 3 days, 4 detections to trigger
deterministic-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test retrospective vaccination. There are 2 rows of units, cattle across the bottom and pigs across the top. Infection spreads across the row of cattle units, resulting in 1 detection per day when the units are turning Clinical. When a cattle unit is detected, a small vaccination circle is drawn, covering just the pig unit directly above that cattle unit.
In this test, vaccination is initiated once 4 infected units have been detected. Retrospective vaccination is given as 3 days.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
For cattle (the bottom row of units), the latent period lasts 1 day, then the unit becomes infectious clinical. Direct contact spread is set up such that each unit infects the one to its right.
Diseased cattle units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 4 units. Retrospective vaccination is set at 3 days. Pig units within 0.75 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. Vaccination resources allow for 1 unit to be vaccinated per day.
What should happen: - Day 1: Unit 0 will be latent. It will infect unit 1. - Day 2-5: On each of these days, a detection will occur, starting with unit 0 on day 2 and ending with unit 3 on day 5. - Day 5: The 4th detection (unit 3) occurs on this day. A vaccination program will be initiated, and the pig unit directly above unit 3 (unit 7) will be added to the vaccination queue. Units 4, 5, and 6 will also be added to the vaccination queue, with unit 4 counting as the oldest request, because those units are in rings around units 0, 1, and 2, which were detected within the last 3 days (retrospective). - Day 6: Unit 4 will be vaccinated (its state will show as vaccine immune on day 7). - Day 7: Unit 5 will be vaccinated (its state will show as vaccine immune on day 9). - Day 8: Unit 6 will be vaccinated (its state will show as vaccine immune on day 9). - Day 9: Unit 7 will be vaccinated (its state will show as vaccine immune on day 10).

variable-test.short-name: vaccination request from exam, cancellation from test
variable-test.description: This test shows a bug that was discovered in April 2014. The test will not fail if run once with the random number generator fixed, but it will fail if run many times without the random number generator fixed.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For sheep, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious subclinical period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 1 day. For cattle, the latent period lasts 1 day and the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days. For pigs, the latent period lasts 1 day and the infectious clinical period lasts 3 days. Immunity lasts 10 days for all types.
For sheep, the probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 1. The probability of reporting vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is also fixed at 1. For cattle and pigs, the probability of detection vs. the number of days a unit has been showing clinical signs is fixed at 0.4, and the probability of reporting vs. the number of days since a public announcement of an outbreak is fixed at 1.
When a diseased unit is detected, a trace out of direct contacts is initiated. The probability of success is 100% but there is a 3-day delay for trace results. Units identified by trace are examined for clinical signs; probability of detection is 2x the normal probability for self-reporting. If the exam does not detect clinical signs, a lab test is done. Tests have 100% sensitivity and specificity, and test results are available immediately.
When a diseased pig unit is detected, all units within 15 km will be vaccinated, excluding detected ones. The delay to immunity is 2 days, and the immunity lasts 5 days. The authorities can vaccinate 3 units per day.
There is no spread or destruction.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 0 (sheep) will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 0 will be Infectious Subclinical. It will expose and infect units 1 and 2 by direct contact. - On day 3 unit 0 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and a trace of direct contacts will be initiated. Units 1 and 2 will be Latent. - On day 4 units 1 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical, but the probability of detection is too low for them to be detected. - On day 5 units 1 and 2 will be Infectious Clinical, but the probability of detection is too low for them to be detected. - On day 6 unit 1 (cattle) will be Naturally Immune and unit 2 (pigs) will still be Infectious Clinical. The probability of detection for unit 2 is still too low for it to be detected. The results of the trace initiated on day 3 will become available and cause both units 1 and 2 to be examined. Unit 2 will be detected, which will trigger a vaccination ring that includes unit 1. Unit 1 will not be detected by clinical signs (it is immune now) so it will be tested. The test will come back positive and that will cancel the request for vaccination of unit 1. It is at this point that the bug will show, because the vaccination list monitor may process the vaccination canceled event before it processes the request for vaccination event. - Nothing more of interest happens on day 7.

variable-test.short-name: re-trigger on 2 detections in any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test re-triggering vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, 2 A units are detected, triggering vaccination the first time. Vaccination is ended, then 2 B units are detected. The fact that vaccination does not start until the 2nd B unit is detected shows that the trigger has reset properly between starts of the vaccination program.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 1 day. This ensures that both A units at the center of circle 1 will be detected, one day apart.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 7 days, and the latent period is 1 day. This ensures that both B units at the center of circle 2 will be detected, also one day apart, but later in the simulation.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 2 units of any type. Units within 1.5 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. The first time vaccination is initiated, there is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day. The second time vaccination is initiated (and subsequent times), the vaccination capacity goes 1 unit on the first day, 2 units on the second day, and 3 units on the third day and forward.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: The A units will be latent and subclinical, not detectable yet. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will be detected. - Day 3: The other A unit will be clinical. It will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - Day 4-6: On each of these days, a unit in circle 1 will be vaccinated. - Day 7: 3 days have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day. - Day 8: 1 B unit will be clinical. It will be detected. For the trigger, which has been reset post-ending of the vaccination program, this counts as the first detection. - Day 9: The other B unit will be subclinical. It will be detected and the vaccination program will be restarted. - Day 10: 2 units in circle 2 will be vaccinated. Note that *two* units are vaccinated: the restart capacity chart goes 1,2,3,... but it is relative to the day of first detection, which was 2 days ago on day 7. - Day 11: 3 units in circle 2 will be vaccinated. - Day 12: The remaining 1 unit in circle 2 will be vaccinated.

variable-test.short-name: re-trigger on 2 detections over 6 days, any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test re-triggering vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, 2 A units are detected, triggering vaccination the first time. Vaccination is ended, then 2 B units are detected. On the day that the first detection of a B unit occurs, the 6 day period also covers the last detection of an A unit. The fact that vaccination does not start until the 2nd B unit is detected shows that the trigger has reset properly between starts of the vaccination program.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 1 day. This ensures that both A units at the center of circle 1 will be detected, one day apart.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 7 days, and the latent period is 1 day. This ensures that both B units at the center of circle 2 will be detected, also one day apart, but later in the simulation.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 2 units of any type over 6 days. Units within 1.5 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. The first time vaccination is initiated, there is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day. The second time vaccination is initiated (and subsequent times), the vaccination capacity goes 1 unit on the first day, 2 units on the second day, and 3 units on the third day and forward.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: The A units will be latent and subclinical, not detectable yet. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will be detected. - Day 3: The other A unit will be clinical. It will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - Day 4-6: On each of these days, a unit in circle 1 will be vaccinated. - Day 7: 3 days have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day. - Day 8: 1 B unit will be clinical. It will be detected. Note that the past 6 days are (8,7,6,5,4,3), and there was a detection on day 3. However, this trigger has been reset post-ending of the vaccination program, so this new detection counts as the only one in the past 6 days. - Day 9: The other B unit will be clinical. It will be detected and the vaccination program will be restarted. - Day 10: 2 units in circle 2 will be vaccinated. Note that *two* units are vaccinated: the restart capacity chart goes 1,2,3,... but it is relative to the day of first detection, which was 2 days ago on day 7. - Day 11: 3 units in circle 2 will be vaccinated. - Day 12: The remaining 1 unit in circle 2 will be vaccinated.

variable-test.short-name: re-trigger 7 days after detection
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test re-triggering vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, vaccination is triggered either a) 3 days after detection in any type, or b) 7 days after detection in type B. One A unit and one B unit are detected early in the simulation, triggering vaccination to begin 3 days later. Vaccination is ended, then a B unit is detected 3 days later. The fact that vaccination does not start until 7 days after the 2nd B unit is detected shows that the time-since-detection trigger has reset properly between starts of the vaccination program.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that only one A unit gets detected.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 8 days. This ensures that one B unit gets detected early in the simulation, and the other several days later.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination begins when 3 days have passed since the first detection in any type or 7 days have passed since the first detection in type B. Units within 1.5 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. Retrospective vaccination is set at 7 days. There is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: No units are clinical yet, no detections. - Day 2: 1 A unit and 1 B unit will be clinical. They will be detected. - Day 3: 1 day after 1st detection. - Day 4. 2 days after 1st detection. - Day 5. 3 days after 1st detection. On this day, and days 6-7, one C will be vaccinated each day. - Day 8: 3 days of the vaccination program have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day. - Day 9: It is now 7 days since the detection of the B unit on day 2. But the trigger has been reset post-ending of the vaccination program, so that detection has been forgotten. new detection counts as the first one. - Day 10: The remaining B unit will be clinical. It will be detected. This is the first detection post-ending of the vaccination program. - Day 17: This is the 7th day after the detection of the B unit. On this day, and days 18-19, one D unit will be vaccinated each day. - Day 20: 3 days of the vaccination program have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day.

variable-test.short-name: re-trigger on EDR 1.5 measured over last 3 days divided by 3 days before that
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test re-triggering vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 6 units of type B.
In this test, vaccination is triggered either a) 1 day after the first detection, or b) by an EDR of 1.5 or higher, measured by detections of B units in the last 3 days divided by detections in the 3 days before that. One A and one B unit are detected early in the simulation, triggering vaccination to begin 1 day later. Vaccination is ended, then 2 B units are detected. The fact that vaccination does not start until additional B units are detected shows that the EDR trigger has reset properly between starts of the vaccination program.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that only one A unit gets detected, early in the simulation.
For production type B, all of the units start subclinical, and the units days left in state are set so that there will be this number of detections over the sequence of days: 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, 1, 0, 2.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination begins when either a) 1 day has passed since the first detection, or b) the EDR is 1.5 or higher, measured by detections of B units in the last 3 days divided by detections in the 3 days before that. Units within 1.5 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. Retrospective vaccination is set at 3 days. There is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: No units are clinical yet, no detections. - Day 2: 1 A unit and 1 B unit will be clinical. They will be detected. - Day 3: 1 day after 1st detection. On this day, and days 4-5, one C unit will be vaccinated each day. - Day 6: 3 days of the vaccination program have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day. - Day 7: 2 B units will be clinical. They will be detected. Note that if you counted the B unit detected back on day 2, the EDR would now be 2.0. But the EDR trigger has been reset post-ending of the vaccination program, so these new detections count as the first ones. - Day 8: 1 B unit will be clinical. It will be detected. EDR = (1+2+0)/(0+0+0) = undefined. - Day 9: No new detections. EDR = (0+1+2)/(0+0+0) = undefined. - Day 10: 2 B units will be clinical. They will be detected. EDR = (2+0+1)/(2+0+0) = 1.5. The vaccination program will be restarted. - Day 11-13: One unit will be vaccinated each day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at 13 days.

variable-test.short-name: re-trigger on detection in 2 groups (A,C) (B,D) or 3 days after first detection
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test re-triggering vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, vaccination is triggered either a) 3 days after the first detection, or b) when detections have occurred in 2 groups. One group contains types A and C, and the other group contains types B and D. One A unit is detected early in the simulation, triggering vaccination to begin 3 days later. Vaccination is ended, then a B unit is detected, then an A unit the next day. The fact that vaccination does not start until the 2nd A unit is detected shows that the number-of-groups trigger has reset properly between starts of the vaccination program.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 8 days. This ensures that one A unit gets detected early in the simulation, and the other several days later.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 8 days, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that only one B gets detected.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination begins when either a) 3 days have passed since the first detection, or b) detections have occurred in 2 groups. One group contains types A and C, and the other group contains types B and D. Units within 1.5 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. Retrospective vaccination is set at 3 days. There is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: No units are clinical yet, no detections. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will be detected. - Day 3: 1 day after 1st detection. - Day 4. 2 days after 1st detection. - Day 5. 3 days after 1st detection. On this day, and days 6-7, one C will be vaccinated each day. - Day 8: 3 days of the vaccination program have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day. - Day 9: 1 B unit will be clinical. It will be detected. Note that if you counted the A unit detected back on day 2, there would now be detections in 2 production type groups. But the number-of-groups trigger has been reset post-ending of the vaccination program, so this new detection counts as the first one. - Day 10: The remaining A unit will be clinical. It will be detected and now there have been detections in 2 production type groups, so the vaccination program will be restarted. - Day 11-12: One unit will be vaccinated each day. The simulation is deliberately stopped at 12 days.

variable-test.short-name: re-trigger on unit waiting 2 days for destruction, no new detection to anchor chart
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test re-triggering vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by any unit waiting 2 days for destruction. The A units are used to activate the trigger. One A unit is detected and marked for destruction early in the simulation. Its wait time causes vaccination to be initiated. Then vaccination is ended, and later in the simulation, the other A unit is marked for destruction because of a trace (not a new detection, but pre-emptive destruction of a trace). The second A units wait time causes vaccination to be re-initiated. The day of re-initiation provides the anchor for day 0 on the axis of the vaccination capacity chart.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that one A unit gets detected early in the simulation, and the other several does not get detected.
There is direct contact between A units, which creates dangerous contacts that can be traced.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 12 days, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that only one B gets detected, later in the simulation.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Destruction of detected diseased units and destruction of traced direct contacts is enabled, but the destruction capacity is zero until 21 days have passed, which creates long wait times.
Vaccination begins after any unit has been waiting 2 days for destruction. Retrospective vaccination is set at 2 days. The first time vaccination is initiated, vaccination capacity is 1 unit per day. Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections. The second time vaccination is initiated, vaccination capacity goes up as 1,2,3 over the first 3 days and then remains at 3 units per day.
What should happen: - Day 1: There is a contact from the subclinical A unit to the latent one. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will again send a contact to the other A unit. It will be detected and marked for destruction. A trace of direct contacts will be initiated. Vaccination will be requested for the ring around the A units. - Day 3: By the end of this day, the A unit counts as having been waiting for 1 day. - Day 4: The A unit counts as having been waiting for 2 days, so vaccination will be initiated. - Day 5: 1 unit will be vaccinated. - Day 6: 1 unit will be vaccinated. - Day 7: 1 unit will be vaccinated. There have been 5 days (days 3-7) with no new detections, so vaccination will be ended. - Day 8: nothing new happens. - Day 9: The trace initiated back on day 2 comes back with results, and the second A unit is marked for destruction. - Day 10: By the end of this day, the second A unit counts as having been waiting for 1 day. - Day 11: The second A unit counts as having been waiting for 2 days, so vaccination will be initiated. Note though that there are currently no units awaiting vaccination. - Day 12: If there were units to vaccinate, there would be capacity to vaccinate 1 today (because vaccination capacity is counted from day 11). - Day 13: If there were units to vaccinate, there would be capacity to vaccinate 2 today. One B unit is detected on this day and provides some units to vaccinate tomorrow. - Day 14: 3 of the units in the ring around the B unit will be vaccinated. The simulation is deliberately stopped on this day.

variable-test.short-name: re-trigger on unit waiting 2 days for destruction, new detection 1
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test re-triggering vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by any unit waiting 2 days for destruction. The A units are used to activate the trigger. One A unit is detected and marked for destruction early in the simulation. Its wait time causes vaccination to be initiated. Then vaccination is ended, and later in the simulation, the other A unit is marked for destruction because of a trace (not a new detection, but pre-emptive destruction of a trace). The second A units wait time causes vaccination to be re-initiated. While the second A unit is waiting, another detection happens, and that detection provides the anchor for day 0 on the axis of the vaccination capacity chart.

variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that one A unit gets detected early in the simulation, and the other several does not get detected.
There is direct contact between A units, which creates dangerous contacts that can be traced.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 9 days, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that only one B gets detected, later in the simulation.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Destruction of detected diseased units and destruction of traced direct contacts is enabled, but the destruction capacity is zero until 21 days have passed, which creates long wait times.
Vaccination begins after any unit has been waiting 2 days for destruction. Retrospective vaccination is set at 2 days. The first time vaccination is initiated, vaccination capacity is 1 unit per day. Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections. The second time vaccination is initiated, vaccination capacity goes up as 1,2,3 over the first 3 days and then remains at 3 units per day.
What should happen: - Day 1: There is a contact from the subclinical A unit to the latent one. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will again send a contact to the other A unit. It will be detected and marked for destruction. A trace of direct contacts will be initiated. Vaccination will be requested for the ring around the A units. - Day 3: By the end of this day, the A unit counts as having been waiting for 1 day. - Day 4: The A unit counts as having been waiting for 2 days, so vaccination will be initiated. - Day 5: 1 unit will be vaccinated. - Day 6: 1 unit will be vaccinated. - Day 7: 1 unit will be vaccinated. There have been 5 days (days 3-7) with no new detections, so vaccination will be ended. - Day 8: nothing new happens. - Day 9: The trace initiated back on day 2 comes back with results, and the second A unit is marked for destruction. - Day 10: One B unit is detected on this day, but this does not trigger vaccination. By the end of this day, the second A unit counts as having been waiting for 1 day. - Day 11: The second A unit counts as having been waiting for 2 days, so vaccination will be initiated. - Day 12: There will be capacity to vaccinate 2 units today, because vaccination capacity is counted from day 10 (the first detection post-ending of the vaccination program). - Day 13: There will be capacity to vaccinate 3 units today. - Day 14: The last unit in the right ring is vaccinated today. The simulation is deliberately stopped on this day.

variable-test.short-name: re-trigger on unit waiting 2 days for destruction, new detection 2
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test re-triggering vaccination. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, vaccination is triggered by any unit waiting 2 days for destruction. The A units are used to activate the trigger. One A unit is detected and marked for destruction early in the simulation. Its wait time causes vaccination to be initiated. Then vaccination is ended. Another detection happens, which does not trigger vaccination (but it does provides the anchor for day 0 on the axis of the vaccination capacity chart late). Later in the simulation, the other A unit is marked for destruction because of a trace (not a new detection, but pre-emptive destruction of a trace). The second A units wait time causes vaccination to be re-initiated.
