variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that one A unit gets detected early in the simulation, and the other several does not get detected.
There is direct contact between A units, which creates dangerous contacts that can be traced.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 7 days, and the latent period is 30 days. This ensures that only one B gets detected, later in the simulation.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Destruction of detected diseased units and destruction of traced direct contacts is enabled, but the destruction capacity is zero until 21 days have passed, which creates long wait times.
Vaccination begins after any unit has been waiting 2 days for destruction. Retrospective vaccination is set at 3 days. The first time vaccination is initiated, vaccination capacity is 1 unit per day. Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections. The second time vaccination is initiated, vaccination capacity goes up as 1,2,3 over the first 3 days and then remains at 3 units per day.
What should happen: - Day 1: There is a contact from the subclinical A unit to the latent one. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will again send a contact to the other A unit. It will be detected and marked for destruction. A trace of direct contacts will be initiated. Vaccination will be requested for the ring around the A units. - Day 3: By the end of this day, the A unit counts as having been waiting for 1 day. - Day 4: The A unit counts as having been waiting for 2 days, so vaccination will be initiated. - Day 5: 1 unit will be vaccinated. - Day 6: 1 unit will be vaccinated. - Day 7: 1 unit will be vaccinated. There have been 5 days (days 3-7) with no new detections, so vaccination will be ended. - Day 8: One B unit is detected on this day, but this does not trigger vaccination. - Day 9: If we were vaccinating, there would be capacity to vaccinate 1 unit today (because vaccination capacity is counted from day 8). The trace initiated back on day 2 comes back with results, and the second A unit is marked for destruction. - Day 10: If we were vaccinating, there would be capacity to vaccinate 2 units today. By the end of this day, the second A unit counts as having been waiting for 1 day. - Day 11: If we were vaccinating, there would be capacity to vaccinate 3 units today. The second A unit counts as having been waiting for 2 days, so vaccination will be initiated. - Day 12: There is capacity to vaccinate 3 units today. - Day 13: There is capacity to vaccinate 3 units today. All units in the right right have been vaccinated now. - Day 14: Nothing new happens. The simulation is deliberately stopped on this day.

variable-test.short-name: 1st/restart trigger on 2 detections in any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test using different triggers for the first initiation of a vaccination program vs. re-starts of the vaccination program. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, a trigger that requires 2 detections is active throughout the simulation. 2 A units are detected, triggering vaccination the first time. Vaccination is ended, then 2 B units are detected, triggering vaccination the second time.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
For production type A, the infectious subclinical period is 1 day, and the latent period is 1 day. This ensures that both A units at the center of circle 1 will be detected, one day apart.
For production type B, the infectious subclinical period is 7 days, and the latent period is 1 day. This ensures that both B units at the center of circle 2 will be detected, also one day apart, but later in the simulation.
Diseased units will be detected (by self-reporting) on their first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination begins when disease has been detected in 2 units of any type. This applies to the first initiation of a vaccination program and any re-starts. Units within 1.5 km of a detected unit will be vaccinated. There is capacity to vaccinate 1 unit per day.
Vaccination is stopped after 3 days with no detections.
What should happen: - Day 1: The A units will be latent and subclinical, not detectable yet. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will be detected. - Day 3: The other A unit will be clinical. It will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - Day 4-6: On each of these days, a unit in circle 1 will be vaccinated. - Day 7: 3 days have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day. - Day 8: 1 B unit will be clinical. It will be detected. Note that since the trigger has been reset post-ending of the vaccination program, this new detection counts as the first one. - Day 9: The other B unit will be clinical. It will be detected and the vaccination program will be restarted. - Day 10-12: On each of these days, a unit in circle 2 will be vaccinated. - Day 13: 3 days have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day, and the simulation will exit.

variable-test.short-name: 1st-only trigger on 2 detections in any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test using different triggers for the first initiation of a vaccination program vs. re-starts of the vaccination program. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, a trigger that requires 2 detections is active only for the first initiation of a vaccination program. 2 A units are detected, triggering vaccination the first time. Vaccination is ended, then 2 B units are detected, but a re-start of vaccination is not triggered.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are the same as for 1st/restart trigger on 2 detections in any type above, but this time the trigger applies only for the first initiation of a vaccination program, not for re-starts.
What should happen: - Day 1: The A units will be latent and subclinical, not detectable yet. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will be detected. - Day 3: The other A unit will be clinical. It will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - Day 4-6: On each of these days, a unit in circle 1 will be vaccinated. - Day 7: 3 days have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day. - Day 8: 1 B unit will be clinical. It will be detected. Note that since the trigger has been reset post-ending of the vaccination program, this new detection counts as the first one. - Day 9: The other B unit will be clinical. It will be detected but the trigger is no longer active and the vaccination program will not be restarted. - Day 10: Nothing new happens. The simulation exits.

variable-test.short-name: restart-only trigger on 2 detections in any type
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test using different triggers for the first initiation of a vaccination program vs. re-starts of the vaccination program. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, a trigger that requires 2 detections is active only for re-starts of a vaccination program. 2 A units are detected, then later 2 B units are detected, but since the only vaccination trigger defined does not apply to first initiation of a vaccination program, no vaccination program is ever initiated.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are the same as for 1st/restart trigger on 2 detections in any type above, but this time the trigger applies only for re-starts of a vaccination program, not to the first initiation.
What should happen: - Day 1: The A units will be latent and subclinical, not detectable yet. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will be detected. - Day 3: The other A unit will be clinical. It will be detected but no vaccination program will be initiated. - Day 4-7: Nothing new happens. - Day 8: 1 B unit will be clinical. It will be detected but no vaccination program will be initiated. - Day 9: The other B unit will be clinical.It will be detected but no vaccination program will be initiated. - Day 10: Nothing new happens. The simulation exits.

variable-test.short-name: 1st-only trigger on 2 detections, restart-only trigger on 1 detection
variable-test.description:
This test is one of a set to test using different triggers for the first initiation of a vaccination program vs. re-starts of the vaccination program. There are 2 rings of units of type C and D; these are the units that will get vaccinated. Inside the first ring are 2 units of type A, and inside the second ring are 2 units of type B.
In this test, a trigger that requires 2 detections is active only for the first initiation of a vaccination program, and a trigger that requires 1 detection is active only for re-starts of a vaccination program. 2 A units are detected, triggering vaccination the first time. Vaccination is ended, then 2 B units are detected. The first detection of a B unit re-starts the vaccination program.
variable-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
variable-test.parameter-description:
The parameters are the same as for 1st-only trigger on 2 detections in any type above, but this time there is another trigger, which applies only for re-starts of a vaccination program, and only requires 1 detection.
What should happen: - Day 1: The A units will be latent and subclinical, not detectable yet. - Day 2: 1 A unit will be clinical. It will be detected. - Day 3: The other A unit will be clinical. It will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - Day 4-6: On each of these days, a unit in circle 1 will be vaccinated. - Day 7: 3 days have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day. - Day 8: 1 B unit will be clinical. It will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - Day 9: The other B unit will be clinical. 1 unit in circle 2 will be vaccinated. - Day 10-12: On each of these days, a unit in circle 2 will be vaccinated. - Day 13: 3 days have passed with no new detections, so vaccination is stopped. No units will be vaccinated on this day, and the simulation will exit.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of a set of tests to check that vaccination can be specified either with just a radius, or a separate inner and outer radius.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
Units of type A and F are latent for 1 day, clinical for 1 day, then immune.
There is no disease spread.
Diseased units are detected on the first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination is initiated after detection of 1 diseased unit. A vaccination circle 3 km in radius is created around a detected A unit. A vaccination ring with inner radius 2 km and outer radius 4 km is created around a detected F unit. There is capacity to vaccinate 100 units per day.
What should happen: - On day 1 units A and F will be Latent. - On day 2 units A and F will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - On day 3, all units within 3 km of unit A will be vaccinated (namely, units B and C). All units within 2-4 km of unit F will be vaccinated (namely, units H and J). Their state will show as Vaccine Immune on day 4. - On day 4, nothing new happens: all of the units that need to be vaccinated have been vaccinated. This will be the last simulation day.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of a set of tests to check that vaccination can be specified either with just a radius, or a separate inner and outer radius.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
Units of type A and F are latent for 1 day, clinical for 1 day, then immune.
There is no disease spread.
Diseased units are detected on the first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination is initiated after detection of 1 diseased unit. A vaccination ring with inner radius 3 km and outer radius 4 km is created around a detected A unit. A vaccination ring with inner radius 1 km and outer radius 2 km is created around a detected F unit. There is capacity to vaccinate 100 units per day.
What should happen: - On day 1 units A and F will be Latent. - On day 2 units A and F will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - On day 3, all units within 3-4 km of unit A will be vaccinated (namely, unit D). All units within 2-4 km of unit F will be vaccinated (namely, unit G). Their state will show as Vaccine Immune on day 4. - On day 4, nothing new happens: all of the units that need to be vaccinated have been vaccinated. This will be the last simulation day.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of a set of tests to check that protective vaccination rings punch holes in each other. In this test, 2 overlapping rings are created on the same day.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
Units of type A and B are latent for 1 day, clinical for 1 day, then immune.
There is no disease spread.
Diseased units are detected on the first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination is initiated after detection of 1 diseased unit. A vaccination ring with inner radius 7/8 km and outer radius 1 1/8 km is created around a detected unit. There is capacity to vaccinate 100 units per day.
What should happen: - On day 1 units A and B will be Latent. - On day 2 units A and B will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - On day 3, units 1, 4, 5, and 6 from the left ring and units 7, 8, 9, and 10 from the right ring should be vaccinated. (Their state will show as Vaccine Immune on day 4.) Units 2, 3, 11, and 12 should not be vaccinated. - On day 4, nothing new happens: all of the units that need to be vaccinated have been vaccinated. This will be the last simulation day.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of a set of tests to check that protective vaccination rings punch holes in each other. In this test, one ring is partially complete when a new, overlapping ring appears.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
Units of type B are latent for 1 day, clinical for 1 day, then immune. Units of type A are latent for 4 days, clinical for 1 day, then immune.
There is no disease spread.
Diseased units are detected on the first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination is initiated after detection of 1 diseased unit. A vaccination ring with inner radius 7/8 km and outer radius 1 1/8 km is created around a detected unit. There is capacity to vaccinate 100 units per day. Vaccination is prioritized by time waiting (oldest requests first), then by size (largest first).
What should happen: - On day 1 units A and B will be Latent. - On day 2 unit B will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, a vaccination program will be initiated, and all of the units in the right ring will be queued for vaccination. - Starting on day 3, one unit can be vaccinated each day. Going by unit size, the right ring will be vaccinated in this order: 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12. On day 3, unit 7 is vaccinated (its state will show as Vaccine Immune on day 4). - On day 4, vaccination of the right ring will continue with unit 8. - On day 5, unit A will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and the units in the left ring will be queued for vaccination. Vaccination of the right ring will continue with unit 9. - On day 6, there are quite a few units in the vaccination queue. Because time waiting (oldest first) has top priority, a unit from the right ring will be picked, and because size (largest first) has second priority, unit 10 will be picked. - On day 7, vaccinating in largest-first order around the right ring would bring us to unit 11. But since the overlapping vaccination ring was created around unit A, units 11 and 12 are now in the hole punched out of the right ring. Unit 1 will be vaccinated (the largest unit in the left ring). - On day 8, vaccinating in largest-first order around the left ring would bring us to unit 2. But units 2 and 3 are in the hole punched out of the left ring. So unit 4 will be vaccinated. - On day 9, vaccination of the left ring will continue with unit 5. - On day 10, vaccination of the left ring will continue with unit 6. - On day 11, nothing new happens: all the units that need to be vaccinated have been. This will be the last simulation day.

deterministic-test.short-name: protective rings punch holes 3 with ring expiry
deterministic-test.description: This is one of a set of tests to check that protective vaccination rings punch holes in each other. In this test, one ring is partially complete when a new, overlapping ring appears.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
Units of type B are latent for 1 day, clinical for 1 day, then immune. Units of type A are latent for 3 days, clinical for 1 day, then immune.
There is no disease spread.
Diseased units are detected on the first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination is initiated after detection of 1 diseased unit. A vaccination ring with inner radius 7/8 km and outer radius 1 1/8 km is created around a detected unit. There is capacity to vaccinate 100 units per day. Vaccination is prioritized by time waiting (oldest requests first), then by size (largest first).
What should happen: - On day 1 units A, B, and C will be Latent. - On day 2 unit B will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, a vaccination program will be initiated, and all of the units in the middle ring will be queued for vaccination. - Starting on day 3, two units can be vaccinated each day. Going by unit size, units 7 and 8 will be vaccinated (their state will show as Vaccine Immune on day 4). - On day 4, vaccination of the right ring will continue with units 9 and 10. Unit A will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and the units in the left ring will be queued for vaccination. - On day 5, vaccination will continue with units 1 and 4 (skipping over units 11, 12, 2, and 3, which are in the hole punched out of the middle ring). Unit C will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and the units in the right ring will be queued for vaccination. - On day 6, vaccination of the left ring will complete with units 5 and 6. - On days 7-9, the right ring will be vaccinated, going two units at a time in largest-to-smallest order. Units 17 and 18 will *not* be skipped because the middle ring was already complete (expired) when the right ring was created. - On day 9, vaccination of the left ring will continue with unit 5. - On day 10, vaccination of the left ring will continue with unit 6. - On day 11, nothing new happens: all the units that need to be vaccinated have been. This will be the last simulation day.

deterministic-test.description: This test checks that both protective and suppressive vaccination rings can be created around a detection.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
Diseased units of production type A are latent for 1 day, clinical for 1 day, then immune.
There is no disease spread.
Diseased units are detected on the first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination is initiated after detection of 1 diseased unit. A suppressive vaccination ring of radius 3 1/3 km and a protective vaccination ring with inner radius 4.5 km and outer radius 6.5 km is created around a detected unit of production type A.
There is capacity to vaccinate 100 units per day.
What should happen: - On day 1 unit 7 will be Latent. - On day 2 unit 7 will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected, a vaccination program will be initiated, and suppressive and protective vaccination rings will be set up as shown in the diagram below. - On day 3 units 1, 2, 12, and 13 will be vaccinated because they are in the protective ring. Units 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, and 10 will be vaccinated because they are in the suppressive ring. (Their states will appear as Vaccine Immune on day 4.) - On day 4, there is nothing new to do. This will be the last simulation day.

deterministic-test.short-name: protective rings do not punch holes in suppressive rings
deterministic-test.description: This test checks that protective vaccination rings do not punch holes in suppressive vaccination rings.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
Diseased units are latent for 1 day, clinical for 1 day, then immune.
There is no disease spread.
Diseased units are detected on the first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination is initiated after detection of 1 diseased unit. A suppressive vaccination ring of radius 3 1/3 km and a protective vaccination ring with inner radius 4.5 km and outer radius 6.5 km is created around a detected unit of production type A. A suppressive vaccination ring of radius 1 1/3 km and a protective vaccination ring with inner radius 2.5 km and outer radius 3.5 km is created around a detected unit of type B.
There is capacity to vaccinate 100 units per day. Vaccination is prioritized by time waiting (oldest requests first).
What should happen: - On day 1 units 7 and 12 will be Latent. - On day 2 units 7 and 12 will be Infectious Clinical. They will be detected, a vaccination program will be initiated, and suppressive and protective vaccination rings will be set up as shown in the diagrams below. - Looking at each unit and what should happen to it: - Units 1 and 2 are in the protective ring around unit 7: they will be vaccinated. - Unit 3 is in the gap between the protective and suppressive rings around unit 7: it will not be vaccinated. - Units 4, 5, 6, and 8 are in the suppressive ring around unit 7: they will be vaccinated. - Unit 9 is in the suppressive ring around unit 7 and the protective ring around unit 12: it will be vaccinated. - Unit 10 is in the gap between the protective and suppressive rings around unit 12, but it is also in the suppressive ring around unit 7: it will be vaccinated. - Unit 11 is in the gap between the protective and suppressive rings around unit 7, but it is also in the suppressive ring around unit 12: it will be vaccinated. - Unit 13 is in the suppressive ring around unit 12 and the protective ring around unit 7: it will be vaccinated. - Unit 14 is in the gap between the protective and suppressive rings around unit 12: it will not be vaccinated. - Unit 15 is in the protective ring around unit 12: it will be vaccinated. - On day 4, the units noted above will show as Vaccine Immune. This will be the last simulation day.

deterministic-test.description: Test to verify a bug fix. In this test, a unit is vaccinated on the same day that it is marked for vaccination as part of a newly created ring.
deterministic-test.author: nharve01@uoguelph.ca
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
Units of type A are latent for 1 day, clinical for 1 day, then immune. Units of type B are latent for 4 days, clinical for 1 day, then immune.
There is no disease spread.
Diseased units are detected on the first day showing clinical signs.
Vaccination is initiated after detection of 1 diseased unit. A vaccination ring with inner radius 7/8 km and outer radius 1 1/8 km is created around a detected A unit. A vaccination ring with inner radius 1/2 km and outer radius 1 1/8 km is created around a detected B unit. Round-robin priority is turned on, then vaccination is prioritized by size, with smaller units being vaccinated first. There is capacity to vaccinate 2 units per day. The minimum time between re-vaccinations is 31 days.
What should happen: - On day 1 units A and B will be Latent. - On day 2 unit A will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and a vaccination program will be initiated. - On day 3, the two smallest units, 5 and 6, should be vaccinated. (Their state will show as Vaccine Immune on day 4.) - On day 4, units 3 and 4 should be vaccinated. - On day 5, units 2 and 1 should be vaccinated, completing the vaccination ring around unit A. Also on this day, unit B will be Infectious Clinical. It will be detected and a vaccination ring will be created. - Over the next several days, units 12 and 11 should be vaccinated, then 10 and 9, then 8 and 7. Units 2 and 3 will not be re-vaccinated because of the minimum time between re-vaccinations. If the bug is present, however, then the program will crash when it considers unit 2 for vaccination (that is the unit that was re-added to the vaccination queue the same day it was vaccinated).
